0	2015-12-31	14 Headlines That Rocked Bitcoin and the Blockchain in 2015	[]	"""I think this just really changes the conversation. There’s smart money out there that is betting big on this and is totally unphased by the whims of the price and what the market is doing. They’re much more concerned about the fundamentals of what’s happening in the network ... and across those metrics
column2: everything is looking great."""

column1: 1	2015-12-31	Why bitcoin’s tech could ‘change everything’ for banks	['Arjun Kharpal']	"Bitcoin may have risen over 35 percent so far this year
column2: but it's the underlying technology behind the cryptocurrency that is exciting the world's major banks. Called the blockchain
column3: it has been heralded as a potentially disruptive force in finance by major institutions
column4: which claim that bitcoin is just the ""opening act"" in something bigger.

column1: D3Damon | E+ | Getty Images
Blockchain works like a huge
column2: decentralized ledger for the digital currency bitcoin which records every transaction and stores this information on a global network so it cannot be tampered with. It's this technology that banks feel can be utilized in areas from remittances to securities exchanges.

column1: Currently
column2: a consortium of more than 25 banks
column3: led by fintech (financial technology) company R3
column4: is developing a framework for applying blockchain technology to markets. CNBC highlights what some of these major banks have been saying this year about the potential of the blockchain.

column1: Goldman Sachs
What if I told you that bitcoin was just the opening act … with the blockchain ready to take center stage
column2: Goldman Sachs said in a note in December
column3: adding that the technology could ""change everything."" Goldman Sachs noted a number of industries and uses that the blockchain could be applied to including voting systems
column4: vehicle registrations
column5: wire fees
column7: trade settlements and cataloguing ownership of art works. ""By removing the need for a middle man
column8: one lowers potential security concerns from hacking to corruption as well as speeding up manual processes that are antiquated and can take too long

column1: JPMorgan
JPMorgan has spent about $9 billion this year on technology investments across the company and a big focus has been on the blockchain. In a note to employees
column2: which was given to CNBC
column3: Daniel Pinto
column4: the head of JPMorgan's corporate and investment bank
column5: said the financial giant has established teams to look into the blockchain among other technology such as robotics.

column1: Barclays

Barclays said in May that bitcoin created a more ""elegant solution than our current payment system"" in many ways but it also ""fell short"" in a number of areas. The British bank said that it envisages a number of other cryptocurrencies will continue to emerge that won't have the flaws of first generation bitcoin
column2: it said in the note. So it's not predicting the end of cryptocurrencies but sees a place for them in the future of blockchain. The first big area cryptocurrencies could work well in is bank transfers and remittances
column3: according to Barclays
column4: as it could make it cheaper and even ""reduce the capital requirements of banks
column5: as it would reduce considerably the counterparty risks.""

column1: A second area of interest is the use of blockchain in securities exchanges with Barclays saying the technology can be ""been abstracted to carry any sort of asset which can be represented digitally."" A third area is in the registration of assets to help insurers keep track of objects
column2: for example. An insurer could keep track of claims and if a car breaks down and an insurer pays for the repairs
column3: both events could be recorded on the blockchain
column4: so it would be more difficult to make a second claim. Other examples Barclays includes is being able to create ""tamper-proof"" online voting and supply chain management.

column1: UBS

UBS has been one of the most open banks about its plans with the blockchain. It has a team called ""Crypto 2.0"" in London conducting research on the technology. The Swiss investment bank said it has explored more than 20 use cases of blockchain and is incubating the best ideas. One of the experiments it carried out was with so-called ""smart contracts"" which it developed into a ""smart bond"". This involved using the blockchain to recreate a bond's issuance
column2: interest calculation
column3: coupon payments and maturation processes. UBS said in this scenario there was no need for pre and post trade intermediaries as the software on the blockchain was specifically configured to automatically handle the flow of information and money between the issuer and the buyer. The test required the creation of a virtual coin which it called ""bondcoin""
column4: which enabled the transfer of value between the parties. Rather than a new virtual currency
column5: bondcoin is linked to real-world currencies and connected to a central bank account.

column1: Deutsche Bank"
2		Stock Market News for December 31
column2: 2015	[]	"The second last trading session was somewhat indicative of the sordid mood markets suffered for most part of this year. Another rout in oil prices dragged the benchmarks down to the red on Wednesday. Also
column3: a slide in Apple sparked a technology sector selloff. Investors were also unnerved after the IMF chief warned of disappointing global economic growth next year. Eventually
column4: yesterday's loss left Dow in the red and S&P 500 is up just 0.2% in 2015.

column1: For a look at the issues currently facing the markets
column2: make sure to read today's Ahead of Wall Street article

column1: The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI) declined about 0.7% to close at 17
column2: 603.87. The Standard & Poor's 500 (S&P 500) dropped over 0.7% to close at 2
column3: 063.36. The tech-laden Nasdaq Composite Index closed at 5
column5: decreasing 0.8%. The fear-gauge CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) surged 7.5% to settle at 17.29. A total of around 2.4 billion shares were traded on Wednesday on the NYSE. Decliners outpaced advancing stocks on the NYSE. For 86% stocks that declined

column1: On many occasions this year the slump in crude prices and the subsequent decline in the energy sector has dragged benchmarks lower. On the second last trading session of the year
column2: it was again the slump in crude prices that damaged the markets the most. The WTI Crude Oil slumped 3.5% to settle at $36.60 and the Brent Crude Oil nosedived 3.7% to close at $36.46.

column1: Oil prices plunged in electronic trading late Tuesday
column2: after American Petroleum Institute reported an unexpected jump in U.S. crude supplies. Eventually on Wednesday
column3: crude slumped as government data revealed that inventories of U.S. commercial crude surprisingly increased by 2.6 million barrels for the week ended Dec 25. This unexpected data from the Energy Information Administration was in contrast to projections from analysts surveyed by The Wall Street Journal that U.S. crude inventories will decline by 1 million barrels.

column1: This obviously dragged the energy sector lower and the 1.4% drop in Energy Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLE) was yesterday's biggest decline among the S&P industry groups. XLE is now down 24.4% year-to-date
column2: the biggest decliner.

column1: Exxon Mobil Corporation ( XOM ) slumped 1.3% and Chevron Corporation ( CVX ) was also down nearly 1.3%. Chevron was the biggest drag on the Dow yesterday. Other key energy shares such as Schlumberger Limited ( SLB )
column2: Occidental Petroleum Corporation ( OXY )
column3: ConocoPhillips ( COP ) and Anadarko Petroleum Corporation ( APC ) declined 1.2%

column1: Separately
column2: the technology sector also suffered losses
column3: pulled down by Apple Inc. ( AAPL ). Shares of the iPhone maker dropped 1.3% after sources mentioned that the company had to pay $348 million to settle a tax claim in Italy. Apple was the biggest drag on Nasdaq and S&P 500.

column1: Technology Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLK) dropped 0.8% yesterday and key stocks such as Facebook
column2: Inc. ( FB )
column3: Verizon Communications Inc. ( VZ )
column4: Intel Corporation ( INTC ) and Cisco Systems
column5: Inc. ( CSCO ) dropped 1%

column1: Dismal global economic growth prospects in 2016 also kept the bearish mood alive. IMF managing director Christine Lagarde said that China's economic slowdown and rising rates in the US are sparking global economic uncertainty. Economies that are reliant on commodities are facing headwinds due to the slump in raw material prices and a slowdown in global trade. Financial threats are increasing in emerging economies and many economies have weak financial sectors. Lagarde said: ""All of that means global growth will be disappointing and uneven in 2016"".
Coming to economic data
column2: the National Association of Realtors reported that its pending home sales index dropped 0.9% in November to 106.9. The drop came after the same had increased in October
column3: following two months of downtrend.

column1: Though Nasdaq is in a comfortable seat to finish the year with decent gains
column2: yesterday's decline left little scope for the Dow to finish 2015 in the green. The blue-chip index is now down 219 points
column4: in 2015. Today's trading session is most likely to be thin
column5: and offers hardly any hope for the Dow to end 2015 with strong gains.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the S&P 500 is up just 5 points this year and thus would hope to see a positive momentum on the last trading session of the year. If the S&P 500 ends in the red
column3: it would be its worst year since 2008. A finish in the green
column4: though with meagre gains
column5: will help it close with yearly gains for the fourth straight time.

4	2015-12-31	The current state of ransomware: CTB-Locker	['About The Author']	"In our series on the current state of ransomware
column2: we previously looked at CryptoWall and TorrentLocker. In this post
column3: we’ll examine a variant called CTB-Locker.

column1: CTB-Locker is a ransomware variant that encrypts files on a victim’s hard disk before demanding a ransom be paid to decrypt the files.
CTB-Locker is noteworthy for its high infection rates
column2: use of Elliptic Curve Cryptography
column3: Tor and bitcoins
column4: and its multi-lingual capabilities.

column1: Infection Vectors
The authors of CTB-Locker are using an affiliate program to drive infections by outsourcing the infection process to a network of affiliates or partners in exchange for a cut of the profits.
The affiliate model is a tried
column2: tested and very successful strategy at achieving large volumes of malware infections. It has been used to generate huge revenues for fake antivirus
column3: click fraud schemes
column4: and a wide variety of other types of malware. It is now being used to distribute ransomware in general and CTB-Locker in particular.

column1: The affiliate scheme for CTB-Locker was first publicly highlighted by the researcher Kafeine
column2: in mid-2014. A 2015 Reddit post claims to be from an actual participant of the affiliate program and provides interesting insight into its workings.

column1: The CTB-Locker authors use a similar strategy to many exploit kit authors by offering a hosted option where the operator pays a monthly fee and the authors host all the code. This makes becoming an affiliate simple and relatively risk-free. The Reddit poster claimed to make 15
column2: 000 (presumably dollars) a month
column3: with costs of around 7
column4: 000. The author also mentions that he only focuses on victims from “tier 1” countries such as the US
column5: UK
column7: as he makes so little money from other regions that it is not worth the time.

column1: Using an affiliate model for distribution means that there are a wide range of different infection vectors for CTB-Locker. We have seen it be distributed through several exploit kits including Rig and Nuclear. However
column2: it is through malicious spam campaigns that the majority of CTB-Locker infections have been observed.

column1: The most commonly seen spam campaigns that distribute CTB-Locker use a downloader component known as Dalexis or Elenoocka. The spam messages themselves follow a wide variety of formats
column2: including missed fax messages
column3: financial statements
column4: overdue invoices
column5: account suspensions and missed mms messages. Here are several examples:

column1: A large proportion of modern day malicious spam arrives as an exe file inside a zip or rar archive. An unusual aspect of Dalexis is that it almost always arrives in a less common archive
column2: typically a cab file.

column1: The archive contains the malicious sample itself
column2: often with a .scr extension and a further archive that contains a decoy document that will be displayed to convince the victim that the attachment was harmless.

column1: The malicious Dalexis sample uses several techniques in an attempt to avoid sandboxes and automated analysis systems
column2: including sleeping for a period of time. Dalexis then downloads the CTB-Locker sample over HTTP in an encrypted form
column3: decodes and executes it.

column1: Execution
When CTB-Locker executes
column2: it drops a copy of itself to the temp directory and creates a scheduled task to enable reboot persistence.

column1: The file system is then iterated through and all files with extensions that match CTB-Locker’s extension list will be encrypted. The desktop background image is changed and CTB-Locker overlays the ransom message and a clickable interface onto the center of the screen.
Unlike some crypto-ransomware variants
column2: CTB-Locker does not require an active internet connection before it starts encrypting files.

column1: Encryption

CTB-Locker stands for “Curve-Tor-Bitcoin-Locker.” The “Curve” part of the name is taken from its use of Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC). ECC is a form of public key cryptography based on elliptic curves over finite fields. Its strength is derived from the elliptic curve discrete logarithm problem. Most file-encrypting Ransomware that uses public key cryptography tends to use RSA
column2: which is based on prime factorization. A benefit that ECC has over RSA is that equivalent security levels can be achieved with much smaller key sizes. For example
column3: a 256-bit ECC key has equivalent security to a 3072-bit RSA key.

column1: The key size advantages that ECC offers may have been a contributing factor in the author’s decision-making process
column2: as they embed a public key into the malware sample and a smaller key takes up less space.

column1: CTB-Locker uses a combination of symmetric and asymmetric encryption to scramble files. The encryption itself is carried out using AES and then the means to decrypt the files are encrypted with the ECC public key. This ensures that only the CTB-Locker authors who have the corresponding private key are able to decrypt the files. For a detailed analysis of the encryption scheme used by CTB-Locker see
column2: this analysis from “zairon.”

column1: CTB-Locker will encrypt files with the following extensions:
pwm
column2: kwm
column3: txt
column4: cer
column5: crt

column1: groups
column2: xlk
column3: xlsb
column4: xlsm
column5: mdb

column1: ai
column2: arw
column3: bay
column4: blend
column5: cdr

column1: pdd
column2: pdf
column3: pef
column4: pfx
column5: ppt

column1: bdcr
column2: bdcu
column3: bpdr
column4: bpdu
column5: ims

column1: This list has been expanded as newer variants have been released.
Originally
column2: encrypted files all had a “.ctbl” extension
column3: however
column4: that was soon changed to have a random extension. It appears that the authors have borrowed at least some of their encryption code from OpenSSL
column5: as large amounts of related strings can be found in the unpacked code.

column1: Network Communication
Since CTB-Locker can start encrypting files without having to contact a command and control server
column2: there does not need to be any network communication until the victim attempts to decrypt their files.

column1: When this happens
column2: all communications are carried out over Tor (this is where the “Tor” from Curve-Tor-Bitcoin-Locker comes in)
column3: usually through proxy websites that act as relays to the Tor Hidden Service that hosts the back-end infrastructure.

column1: When a victim has paid the ransom
column2: CTB-Locker will contact the command and control server
column3: sending a block of data that contains the information needed to derive the key that will decrypt the victim’s files. This block of data can only be decrypted with the master key stored on the server.

column1: Ransom Demand
When all the victim’s files have been encrypted
column2: the ransom message is displayed by changing the desktop background and by overlaying the centre of the screen with the main ransom demand and clickable interface.

column1: This screen informs the victim that “Your personal files are encrypted by CTB-Locker
column2: ” they are told that they have “96 hours to submit payment
column3: ” and they are warned that any attempt to remove the malware from the infected system will result in the decryption key being destroyed – this time limit was lower in earlier versions. The victim can click the “Next” button to start the decryption process or the “View” button to see the list of encrypted files.

column1: CTB-Locker is highly multi-lingual with the ransom note offered in a variety of languages
column2: accessible through the various flag icons at the top of the screen. The choice of languages appears to be at least partially customizable by the affiliate who has purchased this particular CTB-Locker instance
column3: and the available options have grown over time. A recent sample had the following language options – English
column4: French
column5: German

column1: Latvian is an unusual language option
column2: as Latvia is not generally seen as a major target for ransomware and other types of crimeware. This possibly represents the authors looking to break into new markets where awareness is lower
column3: or perhaps the particular affiliate has local knowledge and is better able to launch a successful campaign in that country.

column1: Recent variants of CTB-Locker also offer a way for the victim to verify that their files can be decrypted by unscrambling five randomly selected files for free. This appears to have been introduced as a way to gain the confidence of the victim and increase the likelihood that the full ransom will be paid.
Ransom Payment
When the victim clicks through the ransom interface they are given detailed instructions on how much to pay and how to pay it.
CTB-Locker requires Bitcoins (BTC) to pay the ransom (“Bitcoin” in Curve-Tor-Bitcoin-Locker). The exact amount of BTC is set by the affiliate who has purchased CTB-Locker
column2: though the authors give guidance to help set the ransom amount at a level that is likely to generate maximum revenue. Figure 12 above shows an example demanding 3 BTC. An approximate equivalent amount in the local currency is also displayed – e.g.
column3: 690 Dollars or 660 Euros.

column1: One downside to using Tor hidden services is that reliability can be an issue
column2: meaning that the command and control server cannot be reached when the victim attempts to pay the ransom.

column1: In an attempt to combat this
column2: CTB-Locker attempts to use multiple different Tor proxy servers to reach the hidden service
column3: and also offers manual instructions should the malware sample be removed from the infected machine. These involve visiting the Tor hidden service through a web browser and pasting into a form the public key that the victim is given.

column1: Reliability

Reading through various public support forum postings suggests that in many cases paying the ransom will result in CTB-Locker decrypting the victim’s files. The “Test Decryption” feature is a good indicator that decryption is possible.
However
column2: the victim must still trust that the cybercriminals will make good on their promise after handing over the ransom amount in BTC. There is also the possibility that the server components that host the private keys needed to perform decryption will be taken down
column3: temporarily or permanently
column4: which can make decryption impossible. In that circumstance it is likely that the cybercriminals will continue to accept ransom payments despite knowing there is no way to decrypt the victim’s files.

column1: Statistics
CTB-Locker infections are mostly seen in Western Europe
column2: North America and Australia. These are generally speaking the tier 1 countries described in the Reddit post mentioned above. Victims in these countries appear to be targeted based on the ransomware author’s previous experience of successful payments.

column1: When looking at numbers of samples we can see that the number of actual CTB-Locker samples is much lower than the number of Dalexis samples that are used to download CTB-Locker. This makes sense since the downloader is spammed out in extremely large volumes
column2: which allows security products to add detection very quickly. Making each sample unique by changing a small amount in each file increases the likelihood that some checksum-based protection solutions will fail to detect all of the samples.

column1: Protection
Sophos protects against CTB-Locker at execution with HPmal/Ransom-N
column2: and statically with an array of detection names including: Troj/Ransom-AKW
column3: Troj/Onion-D
column4: Troj/Filecode-B
column5: Troj/HkMain-CT.

column1: Sophos detects the Dalexis/Elenoocka downloader with an array of detection names including: Troj/Agent-AMTG
column2: Troj/Agent-AMKP
column3: Troj/Cabby-H
column4: Troj/Agent-AIRO
column5: Troj/Agent-AMNK

column1: These HIPS signatures often don’t require any updates as they detect on the unpacked memory code irrespective of files on disk that are either packed
column2: obfuscated or encrypted.

column1: Having Sophos HIPS technology enabled is strongly recommended to block ransomware proactively.
If you suspect you’ve been compromised by ransomware
column2: you can remove the malware using our Free Virus Removal Tool. Sadly
column3: there’s not much you can do to get your files back except to pay the ransom – the encryption is too strong to crack.

column1: Apart from having your antivirus up to date
column2: there are additional system changes to help prevent or disarm ransomware infections that a user can apply.

column1: 1. Back up your files.
The best way to ensure you do not lose your files to ransomware is to back them up regularly. Storing your backup separately is also key – as discussed
column2: some ransomware variants delete Windows shadow copies of files as a further tactic to prevent your recovery
column3: so you need to store your backup offline.

column1: 2. Apply windows and other software updates regularly.
Keep your system and applications up to date. This gives you the best chance to avoid your system being exploited using drive-by download attacks and software (particularly Adobe Flash
column2: Microsoft Silverlight
column3: Web Browser
column4: etc.) vulnerabilities which are known for installing ransomware.

column1: 3. Avoid clicking untrusted email links or opening unsolicited email attachments.

Most ransomware arrives via spam email either by clicking the links or as attachments. Having a good email anti-virus scanner would also proactively block compromised or malicious website links or binary attachments that lead to ransomware.
4. Disable ActiveX content in Microsoft Office applications such as Word
column2: Excel
column3: etc.

column1: We’ve seen many malicious documents that contain macros which can further download ransomware silently in the background.
5. Install a firewall
column2: block Tor and I2P
column3: and restrict to specific ports.

column1: Preventing the malware from reaching its call-home server via the network can disarm an active ransomware variant. As such
column2: blocking connections to I2P or Tor servers via a firewall is an effective measure.

column1: 6. Disable remote desktop connections.
Disable remote desktop connections if they are not required in your environment
column2: so that malicious authors cannot access your machine remotely.

column1: 7. Block binaries running from %APPDATA% and %TEMP% paths.
Most of the ransomware files are dropped and executed from these locations
column2: so blocking execution would prevent the ransomware from running."

column1: 5		After Nike's Outstanding Quarter
column2: Here's The Bad News (NYSE:NKE)	[]	"It seems that nothing can stop Nike (NYSE:NKE). The apparel giant reported another outstanding quarter on Friday
column3: and the stock rose 8% in early trading. This sent NKE to yet another all-time high of $125 per share.

column1: Nike has truly had an incredible run. The stock is up 30% just since the beginning of the year while the S&P 500 is actually down 5% in that time. Nike's chart is truly something to behold.
But before investors rush to buy the stock
column2: a word of caution is warranted: Nike is expensive. In fact
column3: the company is more expensive than it's been in the past decade. Not since the 1999-2000 tech bubble
column4: when many stocks experienced wildly distorted valuations
column5: has Nike been so richly valued. That is what worries me about NKE
column6: and why I can't recommend investors buy the stock at its current levels.

column1: Nothing Wrong With Nike As A Business
To be sure
column2: Nike deserves a lot of credit. The company managed to beat analyst estimates
column3: and grew both revenue and earnings in a tough climate. There seem to be little that can hold Nike back from growth. Strong U.S. dollar? No problem. Economic slowdown in China? No problem. Nike generates growth anyway.

column1: It reported 5% revenue growth last quarter
column2: year over year
column3: along with 23% earnings growth
column4: thanks to rising revenue and margin expansion. Excluding the effects of currency fluctuations
column5: the results were even better. Currency-neutral revenue would have grown 14%
column6: which is outstanding. Other key metrics look good as well. World-wide futures orders
column9: or 17% excluding foreign exchange. This successful quarter came on top of a very good fiscal 2015. Last fiscal year
column10: Nike grew revenue 10% to $30 billion. Earnings per share soared 25% last fiscal year.

column1: Valuation Is The Bad News
As the following chart shows
column2: Nike's huge stock price rally in the past several years has mostly been due to multiple expansion. This casts Nike's tremendous decade-long rally into a different light.

column1: Investors are clearly getting more and more enthusiastic about Nike with each passing quarter. Investors have bid the stock up to 31 times earnings
column2: a very high multiple for this company. Its average P/E over the past five years is 23 times. That means NKE is currently valued 35% above its five-year average. And
column3: the company is valued at 26 times forward earnings
column4: which is again well above average. Nike looks expensive across any number of common valuation metrics. It trades for more than 7 times book value
column5: and 19 times enterprise value to EBITDA.

column1: With a valuation profile like this
column2: there simply are not enough margins of safety built in to protect investors against whatever possibility
column3: albeit low
column4: that Nike's future results may not live up to expectations. The company does not offer much of a dividend (it currently yields less than 1%)
column5: so investors aren't getting a dividend margin of safety either.

column1: Sooner or later
column2: all companies
column3: even the former high-flyers
column4: encounter a speed bump in the road. Having at least one margin of safety in your pocket (value
column5: income
column6: or ideally both) is a great way for investors to protect themselves against unforeseen risk.

column1: Nike: Wait For A Pullback
There is no doubt that Nike is a great business
column2: and is one of the world's strongest brands. On the other hand
column3: it's also true that even a great company like Nike can deliver sub-par returns to investors
column4: if too high a price is paid. The company is doing an admirable job of growing and improving its fundamentals in a tough climate. When reading through Nike's earnings materials
column5: it's almost nothing but good news.

column1: The bad news has nothing to do with Nike as a company
column2: it has to do with Nike as a stock. To me
column3: NKE falls into the ""great company
column4: bad stock"" camp. As much as I like Nike as a business
column5: I can't look past the valuation. Ignoring valuation can be a dangerous game that I do not want to play. While I congratulate investors who have held Nike for any length of time
column6: who are sitting on some huge gains
column7: I can't recommend new investors buy the stock today at these levels.

column1: Disclaimer: This article represents the opinion of the author
column2: who is not a licensed financial advisor. This article is intended for educational purposes only and should not be construed as investment advice to any particular individual. Readers should perform their own due diligence before making any investment decisions."

column1: 6	2015-12-31	How To Stem The Global Shortage Of Data Scientists – TechCrunch	['Henry Pickavet'
column2: 'Amy Gershkoff'
column3: 'Amy Gershkoff Is The Chief Data Officer At Zynga'
column4: 'An Adjunct Professor At The University Of California'
column5: 'Berkeley'
column6: 'Where She Teaches Data Science.']	"Data scientist might be considered the “sexiest job of the 21st century
column7: ” with many companies eager to hire data science talent. But 20 years ago the term was barely used
column8: save for a few academic articles.

column1: Even a decade ago
column2: explaining data science to employers was challenging. Few people understood the value of a skill set that combines computer science
column3: statistics
column4: operations research
column5: engineering
column6: business insights and strategy — and the impact it can have on a business.

column1: But things have changed over the last five years. Not only has the term “data science” become commonplace
column2: but data scientists have become highly sought after in the marketplace and lauded in the press.

column1: After all
column2: it was data science that gave consumers personalized shopping recommendations on websites like eBay and Amazon
column3: customized entertainment recommendations on Netflix and Spotify and tailored content and advertising on Facebook
column4: Twitter and Pinterest — all at tens of millions of dollars (if not more) of revenue upside for these businesses.

column1: Over time
column2: organizations started to see the value of data science as the volume of data they had to analyze increased dramatically. For instance
column3: today an estimated 2.5 quintillion bytes of data are created daily. Within this voluminous quantity of data lie insights that could enable companies to gain a competitive edge and provide a better consumer experience
column4: which is why many organizations have now made data science a top priority.

column1: In a KPMG survey of C-suite executives
column2: 99 percent said that analysis of big data was important to their strategy for next year. As the study stated
column3: “Today
column4: the issue is no longer about owning the most data but rather … how to turn data into insights.”

column1: Which is where data scientists come in. The role of a data scientist is to mine enormous volumes of data and pull out key insights. In an era where enterprise-generated data is expected to exceed 240 exabytes daily by 2020
column2: the need for experts trained in extracting insights from data is more important than ever.

column1: So what’s the problem? We have a global talent shortage
column2: and the demand for data scientists continues to grow rapidly
column3: far outpacing the anemic growth in supply. A McKinsey study predicts that by 2018 the number of data science jobs in the United States alone will exceed 490
column5: but there will be fewer than 200
column6: 000 available data scientists to fill these positions. Globally
column7: demand for data scientists is projected to exceed supply by more than 50 percent by 2018.

column1: The need for experts trained in extracting insights from data is more important than ever.

The global talent drought may be partially caused by the dearth of universities that offer data science programs dedicated to preparing the next generation of data scientists. Fewer than one-third of U.S. News & World Report’s Top 100 Global Universities offer degrees in data science. Of the 29 universities that offer data science programs
column2: a mere six make them available to undergraduates (the rest are reserved for graduate students).

column1: Moreover
column2: the average cohort size for one of these data science programs is just 23 students. The small cohort size may be partially attributed to the fact that most of these data science programs tend to be offered to graduate students
column3: and sizes of graduate programs tend to be smaller. Still
column4: at 23 students per cohort
column5: we are unlikely to make a meaningful dent in closing the global data science talent gap.

column1: An analysis of the curricula for these data science programs also suggests cause for concern. Most are focused almost exclusively on the computer engineering aspects of data science
column2: with course titles such as Software Design
column3: Parallel Computing and Software Development.

column1: Largely missing from the data science curricula at many of these universities are courses in statistical analysis
column2: insights and strategy. This oversight may have serious consequences for graduating students and their future employers.

column1: Without training in these other areas
column2: data scientists may be capable of designing an algorithm that is mathematically elegant
column3: but doesn’t make strategic sense for the business. They also may not know how to design an experiment to determine whether the algorithm is effective. In other words
column4: computer science skills alone are insufficient for success as a data scientist in today’s marketplace.

column1: Furthermore
column2: many data science programs lack courses that help students apply their technical data science skills to fields such as marketing
column3: operations
column4: product development and supply chain
column5: and industries such as energy

column1: While there are some universities that have distinguished themselves for having curricula that focus on the multi-faceted aspects of data science
column2: such as New York University
column3: there are still far too few universities producing enough graduates to meet today’s growing demand for data scientists.

column1: There are three steps we can take to help stem this talent shortage:
Increase the number of universities offering data science degrees: To accelerate this
column2: employers can partner with universities to help design and fund the creation of these programs. Accenture’s recent partnership with the University of California
column3: Berkeley to create a new Big Data and Data Science curriculum is one such example. As part of the partnership
column4: Berkeley’s Haas School of Business collaborated with Accenture to create new classes and a lecture series to equip MBA students with the skills needed to analyze big data
column5: including a new course on data analytics.

column1: To accelerate this
column2: employers can partner with universities to help design and fund the creation of these programs. Accenture’s recent partnership with the University of California
column3: Berkeley to create a new Big Data and Data Science curriculum is one such example. As part of the partnership
column4: Berkeley’s Haas School of Business collaborated with Accenture to create new classes and a lecture series to equip MBA students with the skills needed to analyze big data
column5: including a new course on data analytics. Offer data science programs for undergraduates: Enrollment in data science programs must radically increase — cohort sizes of 23 students simply will not close the talent gap fast enough. Offering data science degree programs to undergraduates as well as graduate students can significantly expand enrollment. Universities also should consider offering courses online and during evenings and weekends in an effort to reach non-traditional students.

column1: Enrollment in data science programs must radically increase — cohort sizes of 23 students simply will not close the talent gap fast enough. Offering data science degree programs to undergraduates as well as graduate students can significantly expand enrollment. Universities also should consider offering courses online and during evenings and weekends in an effort to reach non-traditional students. Launch programs that train analysts to become data scientists: Many organizations are flush with analysts who typically have some data science skills in key areas such as statistics. Zynga
column2: for example
column3: recently started a Data Science Transition Program
column4: which enables high-performing analysts to be apprenticed to a data scientist for twelve months
column5: during which time they learn data science skills on the job while taking online data science courses. At the end of the program
column6: the participant becomes an Associate Data Scientist at the company.

column1: Closing the global data science talent gap won’t be easy
column2: but it’s critical to ensure companies have the ability to make data-driven strategic decisions. If companies and universities work together to address the problem
column3: we can better prepare both students and employers for success."
